descrip: Initial settlement period. This age range covers the classic colonisation period for Iceland, up until the decade of the formation of the Alþing in 930AD. Tephra layers can be used to date this period across Iceland
Tephra layers between these two dates cover the classic Little Ice Age period. Although this was a not continuous period of cold and the climate deterioration began earlier.

topics: agricultural landscape , building , erosion , land degredation , human induced change , soil accumulation , charcoal pit , tephra , tephrachronology , burial

descrip: The Landnám Tephra Layer (LTL) is dated to the 870s and coincides with the beginning of Icelandic settlement. All tephra layers younger than this were deposited after the Norse settlement and can be used to study settlement, landscape impacts, erosion and natural processes, as well as for dating archaeological sites and deposits.
cite: Historic tephra layers (i.e. those deposited) post-settlement can be used to date archaeology, landscape change, soil erosion, land degradation.
topics: agricultural landscape , landscape change , erosion , land degredation , human induced change , soil accumulation , natural change , slope stability , woodland decline , volcanic activity , tephrachronology , Historical Chronology , charcoal pits
